study.title: Phytochemical-mediated Modulation of Cytochrome P450 Activity and its Implications in Herb-drug Interactions
study.objectives: To determine whether long-term supplementation of goldenseal, black cohosh, kava kava, or valerian extracts affected CYP1A2, CYP2D6, CYP2E1, or CYP3A4/5 activity.

methods.protocol: Subjects received goldenseal, black cohosh, kava kava, or valerian for 28 days with a 30-day washout period between each supplementation phase.
measurements: debrisoquin urinary recovery ratios for CYP2D6

effects.clinical_relevance: unlikely to produce CYP-mediated herb-drug interactions

study.conclusions: Botanical supplements containing goldenseal strongly inhibited CYP2D6 and CYP3A4/5 activity in vivo. Kava inhibited CYP2E1 and black cohosh weakly inhibited CYP2D6. Valerian appears less likely to produce CYP-mediated herb-drug interactions.
